Options.definition: A term used when it comes to understanding the different variety of stocks in the market.

Stock.definition: Shares of debt issued by a company when it goes live on the market (also known as IPO: Initial Public Offering)

Dividend.definition: A sum of money paid regularly by shareholders of a company.

Initial Public Offering (IPO).definition: When a private company sells shares of its stock to the general public for the first time, essentially "going public" to raise money, pay off debts, or fund growth, becoming a private entity to a public entity whose ownership is traded on a stock exchange.

Flotation.definition: Process for a company going private to public.

Market Designers.definition: People in power who take a macro approach to aligning market reactions and results to their desired outcomes, i.e. to solve allocation problems within a market.
Market Designers.location: Market Design paper by Georg Rilinger

Modularization.definition: Breaking down complex systems into smaller, independent, changeable units.
Modularization.location: Market Design paper by Georg Rilinger
